entries.content: Use a permission-based opener at the start of a call to earn the right to speak.
Permission-based opener example: 'Do you want to hang up or do you want me to have 30 seconds?'
Give the prospect a choice in the opener; it increases the likelihood they'll engage.
The first goal in a sales interaction is always to intrigue the prospect.
Intrigue statement formula: 'I help people who want to improve their [Blank] by doing [Blank] without [Blank].'
Ensure your intrigue statement includes: 1) Target persona, 2) What they want to do, and 3) What they want to avoid.
The second goal, after intrigue, is to get the prospect into a two-way conversation.
Ask questions that make the prospect think deeply about their situation.
Base your conversation questions on the three points of your intrigue statement.
Use open-ended questions that start with 'How', 'What', 'Why', 'Tell me', or 'Explain'.
The third goal, after conversation, is to get permission to schedule a meeting.
Permission-based meeting request: 'Based on this conversation, would it make sense to put some time on the calendar to explore this more?'
Request the meeting based on the value provided during the conversation.
Follow the sales process goals sequentially: Intrigue -> Conversation -> Meeting.
Use an inquisitive, curious, and exploratory tonality, not an aggressive or 'pitchy' one.
Be prepared for every call by understanding your ICP, product, market, problem, and solution.
Confidence is crucial because people buy from those they like, know, and trust.
Build sales confidence through practice ('reps'), consistent action ('doing'), and learning from failure.
